results.title: La Femme du Boulanger = the Baker's Wife
results.brief_description:
A village baker refuses to bake bread when his attractive young wife runs off with a handsome shepherd, a situation that forces the bread-less villagers to take action. Pagnol, combining the best of his humour with sympathetic characterizations of Provencal life, gives an individual drama of infidelity a collective dimension.

Credits: Producer, Charles Pons ; director, Marcel Pagnol ; writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Georges Benoit, Roger Ledru ; music, Vincent Scotto ; editor, Suzanne de Troeye.
Cast: Raimu, Ginette Leclerc, Fernand Charpin, Robert Vattier, Edouard Delmont, Maxilienne, Robert Bassac, Marcel Maupi, Paul Dullac, Charles Moulin.

results.title: La Femme de Ma Vie = Woman in My Life
results.brief_description:
Simon is a virtuoso violonist and an alcoholic. One night, he collapses during a live-to-air TV concert. Following the incident, he is submerged with shame and avoids his wife, Laura. Laura is the women to whom Simon owes his career ever since she set up and managed the orcherstra Simon plays in. In the depth of his crisis, Simon meets Bernard who has been through the same experiences. As Bernard undertakes to heal Simon he unwittingly becomes Laura’s rival who cannot accept to see Simon receiving assistance from anybody but her. Awards: French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) - Best New Director of a Feature Film 1987.

Credits: Producer, Yannick Bernard ; director, Regis Wargnier ; writers, Catherine Cohen, Alain Le Henry, Regis Wargnier, Alain Wermus ; photography, Francois Catonne ; music, Romano Musumura.
Cast: Christophe Malavoy, Jane Birkin, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Beatrice Agenin, Elsa Lunghini, Florent Pagny, Dominique Blanc, Didier Sandre, Andrzej Seweryn.

results.title: La Femme Aux Bottes Rouges = the Woman with Red Boots
results.creator_credit: Juan Bunuel, Raymond Vogel and Jordan Bojillon
results.brief_description:
Francoise Leroy, a young and unknown writer, has supernatural gifts. She becomes acquainted with Perou, an old millionaire who loathes artists. Perou is smitten by the young woman whom he saw naked once. He starts stalking her and discovers she lives with Richard, a painter, but that she is secretely attracted to Marc, her publisher, to whom she sends letters. Perou intercepts these letters and sends replies to Francoise, pretending to be Marc. Then, he proceeds to help Marc, who is married, to kill his wife. Finally, he invites the young woman and her two rival lovers to spend time at his house. There, the final show down takes place between an old man who has already destroyed several artists’ lives and the young woman with strange powers.

Credits: Producers, Jordan Bojillon, Raymond Vogel ; director, Juan Bunuel ; writers, Jean-Claude Carriere, Juan Bunuel, Pierre-Jean Maintigneux, Clem Wood ; photography, Leopold Villasenor.
Cast: Catherine Deneuve, Fernando Rey, Jacques Weber, Adalberto-Maria Merli, Jose Sacristan, Emma Cohen, Laura Betti.

results.title: La Drolesse = the Hussy
results.creator_credit: Jacques Doillon, Yves Robert and Daniele Delorme
results.brief_description:
Twenty-year old misfit Francois kidnaps gawky Mado, an 11 year-old who is neglected by her family. Francois locks up Mado in his attic. Instead of feeling fear, Mado enters into the spirit of the abduction, and they joust with one another, increasingly finding love and comfort in their relationship. Doillon’s intimate, small-scale films are marked by recurrent themes of Oedipal and gender conflicts - especially between fathers and daughters - which, although not strictly autobiographical, often rework events from his life. Doillon’s mise-en-scene favours pared-down, claustrophobic settings and situations, contrasting with the violent emotions depicted. Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. “The comapnion to French cinema”. London: BFI Publishing, 1996.

Credits: Producers, Daniele Delorme, Yves Robert ; director, Jacques Doillon ; writer, Jacques Doillon ; photography, Philippe Rousselot ; art direction, Jean-Denis Robert.
Cast: Claude Hebert, Madeleine Desdevises.

results.title: La Dolce Vita = The Sweet life
results.creator_credit: Federico Fellini, Giuseppe Amato and Riama Film
results.brief_description: A look at the decadent lifestyle of Roman high society, seen through the eyes of a gossip columnist who aspires to straight journalism, but is unable to break away from his debauched life. “La Dolce Vita” still remains one of the most popular of all Fellini’s films. Cast includes Marcello Mastroianni and Anita Ekberg. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: La Direction des Acteurs
results.brief_description:
This short piece was filmed at the time Jean Renoir was preparing ‘The River’. In order to demonstrate his conception of directing, he asks Gisele Braunberger to audition for the role of the young protagonist of ‘The River’.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Gisele Braunberger ; photography, Edmond Richard.
Cast: Jean Renoir, Gisele Braunberger.

results.title: La Dentelliere = the Lacemaker
results.creator_credit: Claude Goretta, Yves Gasser, Yves Peyrot, Citel Films, Filmproduktion Janus and Action Films
results.brief_description:
Pomme works as a hairdresser and lives with her protective mother in Paris. She goes on a holiday to the seaside town of Cabourg with a more worldly friend. There she forms a relationship with Francois, a young student, and they decide to live together in Paris. Social differences soon emerge. While Francois is garrulously intellectual, Pomme is reserved, incapable of communicating with Francois and his friends but maintaining a mysterious inner radiance. Goretta has described his film as ‘a genre painting’ in narrative form and it is constructed in a series of brief fragmentary scenes which form a picture without evident narrative connections. With its narrative ellipses - eloquent silences and observation of Pomme’s mysterious inner life - Goretta’s film resembles Bresson’s ‘Une Femme Douce’. Also available on VH.

Credits: Producers, Yves Peyrot, Yves Gasser ; director, Claude Goretta ; writers, Claude Goretta, Pascal Laine ; photography, Jean Boffety ; music, Pierre Jansen.
Cast: Isabelle Huppert, Yves Beneyton, Florence Giorgetti, Anne-Marie Duringer, Michel de Re, Monique Chaumette.

results.title: La Denonciation (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
Paris, 1961. Michel Jussieu, film producer, discovers the body of murdered political activist Georges Yvain on his way to a party. Haunted by guilt since he revealed under torture the names of members of his Resistance movement, Michel refuses to assist the police in the murder investigation and decides to conduct his own enquiry. Famous ‘Cahiers du Cinema’ critic Jacques Doniol-Valcroze films in a style very much influenced by the French New Wave the torments of a man coming to grips with his own guilt.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger, director, Jacques Doniol-Vacroze ; writer, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; photography, Henri Raichi ; music, Georges Delerue ; editor, Bob Wade ; assistant director, Jean-Louis Bunuel.
Cast: Maurice Ronet, Francoise Brion, Sacha Pitoeff, Michel Lonsdale, Jean-Claude Darnal, Nicole Berger, Raymond Gerome, Francois Maistre.
